title: What (And How) To Eat for Nausea

content: When nausea strikes, it can be miserable. An uneasiness in the stomach can make it hard to function, especially when there’s a lingering threat of vomiting. As a dietitian in a gastroenterology practice, I see many patients suffering from recurrent nausea. In addition to a side effect of medications and pregnancy, nausea can be caused by common conditions affecting the stomach, including gastritis, peptic ulcers, GERD, functional dyspepsia (chronic indigestion), and gastroparesis (delayed stomach emptying). Although eating may seem like the last thing you want to do with nausea, a variety of foods and diet strategies may provide relief while also keeping you properly nourished.

Going too long without eating can worsen nausea . Consider the simple motto: “An empty stomach is an acid stomach.” Long stretches without food can lead to a buildup of digestive fluids that normally get utilized with digestion. This can spell trouble for multiple stomach conditions like gastritis, peptic ulcers, GERD, and dyspepsia, which tend to feel better with food as a buffer. While an overfly full stomach can also worsen symptoms, evenly spaced eating helps to regulate acid and may rid you of or prevent your nausea.

sections.heading: Your body needs enough nutrients to function well
content: . Although your instinct may be to avoid food when you have nausea, prolonged fasting can backfire. Without the right nutrition coming in, your body may not have the nutrients and strength needed to overcome an illness, infection, or other physical stress that may be causing the nausea to begin with. It may be necessary to occasionally skip food during active nausea, but recurrent nausea (such as with gastroparesis or functional dyspepsia) calls for setting a more proactive nutrition plan.
The Best Foods for Nausea
Tolerance may vary, depending on the cause of your nausea and your taste preferences, though foods that are generally neutral and gentle on the stomach are a good starting place:
Low-odor foods. Bland foods are friendly for digestive upset since the taste and scent of many flavorings, spices, and seasonings can aggravate a low appetite.
Cold foods. Chilled and frozen foods, such as smoothies, ice pops, or plain cereal with cold milk, are low in scent and may feel additionally soothing in your mouth and throat.

sections.heading: Low-fat foods.
content: While fatty foods can slow down stomach emptying and add to an already irritated or inflamed stomach, low-fat foods like low-fat dairy, egg whites, fruit, and starches can clear the stomach faster and more comfortably.
Ginger. As one of the few foods with science-backed anti-nausea properties, ginger can soothe the stomach despite its more potent flavor.

Soft textures. Foods that are physically less bulky or coarse, such as ripened peeled fruit, cooked vegetables, and bread products, are faster to digest and less taxing of a slow, irritated, or hypersensitive stomach.
Starches. Foods like rice, potatoes, and bread products have multiple anti-nausea properties: They’re generally soft, low in fat, and mild in flavor and scent.
Liquids. Drinkable options such as smoothies and shakes can be rich in nutrients and are generally the safest option for troubled stomachs.
Supportive Eating Practices
It’s not just what you eat that can affect digestive symptoms like nausea, but how you eat it.

sections.heading: Small portions.
content: Instead of aiming for a full meal, eating mini servings – even a few bites or sips at a time – can help you gradually increase your intake.
Upright position. Eating or drinking while lying down can cause indigestion and acid reflux. If you’re on a couch or bed, prop yourself up with a comfortable pillow .

Try, try again. It may feel discouraging if you’re unable to eat, but don’t assume you should fast for the rest of the day. Switch to another activity for a bit and return to attempt a small portion of food or liquid nutrition.
Loose clothing. Opt for comfort, as tightness around your waist or midsection may add to stomach symptoms.
Calming ambience. When your appetite is low, incorporate soothing environmental elements such as happy music, a nice view, fresh air, or friendly company.
Deep breaths. Taking deep breaths into your abdomen can help with digestive comfort.
When You Can’t Keep Any Food or Liquids Down
In some cases, nausea can be so severe that tiny amounts of food or even water alone can trigger vomiting. When this happens, it’s best to speak with your doctor for further guidance.

sections.heading: Help for Chronic Nausea From a Dietitian
content: It’s OK if your diet doesn’t look perfectly balanced when you’re eating through nausea. However, if you have a chronic condition such as gastroparesis, GERD, or functional dyspepsia and find yourself on a limited diet, it’s best to work with a dietitian to ensure you meet your nutritional needs.
